title: Before 1 January 2021, will the Council of the European Union request the consent of the European Parliament to conclude a European Union-United Kingdom trade agreement?
preds: Since it is past 12:00 p.m. GMT, I think this question is over.
I give up on this one, I hope it still resolves as yes, but I don't think it will.

It's past the end of the work day in Brussels and a quick news search indicates that this does not appear to have happened yet. If it has happened, then there are no news articles or press releases from the Council of the European Union or the European Parliament stating as such. What a rollercoaster of a question. I hope better resolution criteria are chosen for future questions similar to this one.
I'm not informed on the technicalities of the EU requesting consent, reducing confidence significantly.
Looks like it's not going to happen before 2021

100 > 0
This question ist torture until the very end.
Following @keith-huggins here.

The European Parliament must give consent to the Council to conclude the trade agreement. 
'Next year, the Council will adopt the decision on the conclusion of the EU-UK Trade and Cooperation Agreement, once the European Parliament has given its consent and once all procedures necessary for the entry into force have been completed, according to the release.'
It would seem that the consent is provisional at this time. Some part of the EU (such as Wallonia have done before) or Macron under pressure from Fishermen, could delay the conclusion.
Therefore the 'conclusion' as specified in the question will not happen before 1st January 2021. https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-55476625
https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/IP_20_2531
https://www.instituteforgovernment.org.uk/explainers/future-relationship-eu-ratification
http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2020-12/30/c_139627916.htm

Lesson not to engage with questions that have a high process fetish ... especially when such processes are not entwined with the main outcome. Nobody in real world cares about pedantic/ non-essential processes. I heard alot is UK and EU going to do a trade deal ... Not so much is the Council of the EU going to get to stage 23 of its process.
I don't think my forecasts have ever looked this stochastic before
Returning to my intuition as of 21 Dec 2020, amid new evidence and peer pressure :-)

Reading all the posts below, I have stopped believing the council will manage to examine the proposal for conclusion by tomorrow end of the day. Most likely there is no need to rush this “examination” and this part of the process will be done next year.
Based on the research done by @Okanaganopolis and the fact that there is only one day to go.

Still a bit unsure about the process even after the investigation made by @Okanaganopolis. I think it is likely the Council will be asking the EP for consent after the new year now, but only goes down to 50% as I've been rather low on this question before. If I would come in fresh without previous predictions to this question I would probably put the chances at 5%. Yes: -50
Down to 0 after the Sterling work from @Okanaganopolis
Based on the notes re. email from EU.
Please come up with better formulations for questions in the future. Not sure if I'm a winner or a loser of this technicality, but I anyway found the question exceptionally difficult to forecast.

And the final 1% falls away with this sterling investigatory work by @Okanaganopolis and the response he's received from the Council directly: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1210182 Confirmed that the Council of the EU have no intention of doing anything more towards Step 23 this side of New Year.  This seems to be about as conclusive as it comes!

The final nail in the coffin has just been slammed home. I was *quite* sure, yesterday, that step 23 was triggered and I'd made my winning bet and explained my reasons to the crew. BUT, as a last test of my theory, I emailed the EU directly to find out if they'd confirm, or not... In my email is the response from the EU apparatchik  who WROTE the COMMUNICATION of the WRITTEN PROCEDURE https://data.consilium.europa.eu/doc/document/CM-5525-2020-INIT/en/pdf  Below is the whole thread if anyone cares to read it. The punchline, though, is "None".  From: DECAESTECKER Jean Paul <jeanpaul.decaestecker@consilium.europa.eu>

Cc: RUIZ NIEVAS Maria <maria.ruiz-nievas@consilium.europa.eu>

Sent from my iPhone On 30 Dec 2020, at 11:33, Paul Bouchard <paul@bpwood.com> wrote:

Maria. Thx for responding.  So... “Signing, not Concluding.” Presuming UK signs their side, is there any Council actions left re “concluding” which would/could/will happen before Jan 1?
That’s when I’ll lose the beer bet, and why I ask.  Thank you so kindly  ________________________________________
From: RUIZ NIEVAS Maria <maria.ruiz-nievas@consilium.europa.eu>

Dear Mr Bouchard, - the procedure only addressed the Council Decision on signing, not the Council Decision on conclusion of the Trade and Cooperation Agreement.
- it is only about the outcome of the procedure that the EP is informed, not about some hypothetical future stages. I hope this helps.
Kind regards.

Re: EU-UK TCA

Hi, Maria, 
Cc: Jean Paul

Greetings from Canada. I read the press release today: https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/press/press-releases/2020/12/29/eu-uk-trade-and-cooperation-agreement-council-adopts-decision-on-the-signing/# QUESTION: Through the “Written Procedure”, has a request for the consent of the European Parliament to conclude a European Union-United Kingdom trade agreement effectively occurred?

I think* so, because (as cited in the COMMUNICATION of the WRITTEN PROCEDURE in a separate release by your colleague, Jean Paul https://data.consilium.europa.eu/doc/document/CM-5525-2020-INIT/en/pdf) “The European Parliament will be informed in accordance with Article 218(10) TFEU” At the heart of it, my theory is: Article 218 (10) states that the European Parliament must be "immediately and fully informed at all stages of the procedure" and is the de facto “request for consent”, even though the vote for that doesn’t happen till the next plenary session. A much clearer press release to confirm the “request for consent of the European Parliament” was the CETA (Canada) agreement in 2016, https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/press/press-releases/2016/10/28/eu-canada-trade-agreement/ which was also through a “Written Procedure” and stated the “request for consent” more clearly than today’s EU-UK TCA release  *I have a large BEER bet on this topic, so some clarity from you or your team will be greatly appreciated. All the very best from Canada to our friends in Europe and may we all appreciate that 2020 is almost over! 😊 pb
Humbled by this. I've never been more flummoxed by the technical technicalities of a question.  That's been The Life Lesson of 2020, soon to be Hindsight, which is, of course 20/20

Now that the UK and EU have signed the deal and there is no update from the Council I am reverting to my historical position.  I have been blindsided in the last few days by applying logic to the technicalities of a political process. Who'd have thought the UK could ratify an agreement signed by both sides and provisionally applied by the EU when the EU hasn't fully agreed internally on the agreement and its actual legal-linguistic content. Thanks for all the counter arguments from @Mark_T, @LunaSol et al!
Downgrading a lot thanks to the explanation of where we are from @mark_t . Thought I was in for a big win on this one too. Did I mention I hate this question 😃

I'm sticking with my 100% more out of principle than anything else (I can see that the there is a significant possibility that the saisine is not sent before 1st Jan and "real" likelihood of the OP is more like 25%). I think it's a shame that it comes down to somewhat nuanced reading of press releases to determine the result when in practice the arguments during the forecasting were about whether a deal would be reached at all. In fact, a deal has been agreed and now voted on by both sides (and expected to be signed by both sides today). Was it really the intent of the question proposer to have the distinction between stage 21/22 and 23 of the doc be a significant factor in the forecast ?
I've been lowering my estimates since the December 28th NOTE was added to the question. I think @Mark_T explained it well.

For me, a careful reading of Step 22 and Step 23 has been the most revelatory in the last 7 days and gets the most weighting (from me) in this specific questions case (again, full credit to @samglover97 and @Wildwood2000 for encouraging me to check my own assumptions and apply a little more fox to last week's hedgehog!). Step 22 covers the aspect of provisional implementation which is where we are. This was a definite priority to stave of WTO terms as the most immediate and costly danger to both sides. With the release of the written procedure and the signatures of both sides in place today this danger is averted. Pressure is off and everyone can take a breath to enjoy (in a COVID conscientious way) their New Years holiday. Now, it is still POSSIBLE that the EU Council will be such enthusiastic eager beavers (after 9 months of gruelling negotiations?) that they'll jump straight into Step 23 in the evening of the 30th December or on New Years Eve (31st December 20) and start "examining the proposal for conclusion" and then get drafting the 'saisine' request for approval.  Hence why I can't say its "impossible" through the award of a 0% probability forecast. I found an example of the CETA 'saisine' request here (its in French of course but google translate does a passable job): https://www.conseil-constitutionnel.fr/decision/2017/2017749DC.htm. Note this is a legalese heavy and quite lengthy document (i.e. likely took some time to prepare). In counter argument to this point, it may be that the Council of the EU have got this request for consent prepared already. But... There are also reports of some pretty egregious "copy and paste" errors in the text of the current agreement (e.g. the rather hilarious mentions of Netscape and Mozilla Mail - defunct since the late 90's!: https://twitter.com/billatnapier/status/1342877839008411648?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw%7Ctwcamp%5Etweetembed%7Ctwterm%5E1342935639663259648%7Ctwgr%5E%7Ctwcon%5Es2_&ref_url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.bbc.co.uk%2Fnews%2Ftechnology-55475433) that will need to be cleaned up before the Council are likely to feel ready to present the deal to the EU Parliament under a "request for consent". This cleaning up would probably take place in the "examine the proposal for conclusion" part of Step 23 (before request for consent is published) and will likely take some time given the high probability of mistakes (like the above) made during the initial rush to publish the provisional document. Given the above and the lack of WTO imperative with the provisional arrangement in place I just don't see the reason or the likelihood that any side (UK or EU) are going to be in a rush to get the request for consent out this side of 2020. Facing a brutal truth for a second, the only people now in a rush for Step 23 to resolve are us forecasters who thought we'd got a massive forecasting (Brier Score) win with our "against the herd" (and ultimately accurate) forecasts of the Christmas Eve Trade Deal announcement. Whilst galling to be stumped at the last on what many are calling a "technicality" (within a technical question!), our desire for a forecasting win is probably not something that's going to be foremost in the minds of the members of the Council of the EU and not something they're likely to give up their New Years Eve over. In case I miss it, could I wish everyone a happy, safe and prosperous New Year. Lets all do our very best to make 2021 a better year (it shouldn't be too hard)!

Now that the EU27 has provisionally accepted this Brexit deal, it's down to the UK Parliament to decide. I think it is simpler when one views this part of the process. Stop jumping to the end game and follow the formal process necessary to get from one section to the consent section. Right Now it is just a provisionally accepted Brexit deal. The UK Parliament votes on Dec 30, 2020 and that then is forwarded to the EU on the 31st of December as accepted. Until that happens the EU is held up from then having their final vote and formal request for consent. That the EU has reported will occur in the new year. NO Rush inasmuch as there exists a provisional deal in place, Now that the EU27 has provisionally accepted this Brexit deal, it's down to the UK Parliament to decide. https://youtu.be/iOETyKcZVR0 Article 218(10) & Article 217 TFEU non relative to consent at this point only covers the number of member states necessary to finalize the Deal. Final consent is subject to the UK Parliament vote on Dec 30th and approval then being sent to the EU for finalization of the process. Press releases of the Canada deal non relative to the process of the EU UK deal at this point, it was only an example, not a resolution criteria. Confirmation biases seems to exists as the largest part of your thinking process at this time. The deal was reached pass the time frame for finalization in 2020

The toughest puzzle ever. I'm in for the win...in my view the "Written Procedure" is the key and IS the method through which the *consent of the European Parliament* is "requested"  The ELUSIVE "Request for the consent of the European Parliament" is a part of the "Written Procedure" and the precise subset is THIS: "The European Parliament will be informed in accordance with Article 218(10) TFEU". Today's event COMMUNICATION, (shown to us by @User01 ) is a "WRITTEN PROCEDURE" and shows us https://data.consilium.europa.eu/doc/document/CM-5525-2020-INIT/en/pdf  Halfway down page 3 it says: "The European Parliament will be informed in accordance with *Article 218(10) TFEU*." *Article 218(10) TFEU* is explained here: https://www.instituteforgovernment.org.uk/explainers/future-relationship-article-218 explains: 
excerpt....
              "Article 218 (10) states that the European Parliament must be "immediately and fully informed at all stages of the procedure".  Further confidence: The Canada deal was the cited example. Compare the press release then to the EU-UK one today. CANADA case: https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/press/press-releases/2016/10/28/eu-canada-trade-agreement/ which says in the OPENING PARAGRAPH: 
On 28 October 2016, the Council adopted by written procedure a package of decisions on the comprehensive economic and trade agreement with Canada (CETA), including:     a decision on signature of the agreement
    a decision on the provisional application of the agreement
    *a decision to Request the Consent of the European Parliament for the conclusion of the agreement* The ELUSIVE "Request for the consent of the European Parliament" is a part of the "Written Procedure" and the precise subset is THIS "The European Parliament will be informed in accordance with Article 218(10) TFEU". SO, I conclude, as is so eloquently phrased in the Canada release, steps 21,22, and 23 are ALL triggered through the "Written Procedure" @Wildwood2000 @User01 @DelapsusAngelus @WBHumanoid @CUTNPASTE @bh4eh @Mark_T  If I'm wrong, please show me what I missed!... thx.

In my assessment there is now <5% chance of a request for consent being made in 2020 (logically in the dark hours of the 30th Dec 20 or the 31st Dec 20) based on: 1.  The lack of imperative to burn midnight oil on New Years Eve (a holiday for most normal people!) once a newly minted provisional agreement is in place to avoid WTO terms / hard Brexit until full agreement is given 2.  Signatures being applied to the document tomorrow (with a VERY small chance BJ's deal is kyboshed at the 11th hour by the UK Parliamentary vote, also taking place tomorrow) which is the obvious precursor to STEP 23 (consent being requested). This line in the bulletin I found interesting: "Next year, the Council will adopt the decision on the conclusion of the EU-UK Trade and Cooperation Agreement, once the European Parliament has given its consent and once all procedures necessary for the entry into force have been completed." https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/press/press-releases/2020/12/29/eu-uk-trade-and-cooperation-agreement-council-adopts-decision-on-the-signing/ Whilst not conclusive, this does seem to imply that everything beyond tomorrow's signatures will take place in the New Year.  And who can blame them: these people need a break!

Updating my forecast from 100% - the deal is now starting to look like a fudge.  The most pertinent text (along with all its errors) is this:
https://data.consilium.europa.eu/doc/document/CM-5525-2020-INIT/en/pdf A number of EU states have concerns around the legal basis for the deal and look to scrutinise it in the future before completing it. The Dutch note: "The application of the agreements on a provisional basis, pending the completion of the procedures necessary for their entry into force, allows the European Parliament and the Council to appropriately scrutinize the envisaged decision on the conclusion of the Agreements, which is to be taken by unanimity in the Council, and the text of the Agreements." - which makes it sound as if they have not agreed to seek to conclude yet. But they've also just agreed to sign said deal and apply it provisionally any way - is there an historical precedence for states signing an agreement (which looks to be ratified by the UK tomorrow) without one side actually agreeing on the legalise of the agreement they've signed?  There is no specific mention of a request for consent, which may come tomorrow after it is signed.  While I have used this as an excuse to learn more about the functioning of the EU, my current judgement =   ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

New update: "The Council has today adopted, by written procedure, the decision on the signing of the EU-UK Trade and Cooperation Agreement and its provisional application as of 1 January 2021, pending the consent of the European Parliament and conclusion by the Council decision next year ... The agreement will now be signed by the two parties on 30 December 2020" [1]. OK so now Step #22, "If the Council agrees to provisionally apply the agreement, the EU can notify the depositories of the agreement that it is provisionally applying the agreement, either fully or in part" [2], has been completed. Now we are on the verge of Step #23 — "After both sides sign, the Council examines the proposal for conclusion and sends the agreement to the Parliament for its consent (approval). This is known as a 'saisine'" [2]. As mentioned in the press release today [1], the Council has provisionally approved the agreement and has scheduled a signing by both sides tomorrow, 30 December. According to the full text of today's Council decision, the next step is that the European Parliament will "be informed in accordance with Article 218(10) TFEU" [3]. A relevant line in Article 218 is "The European Parliament shall be immediately and fully informed at all stages of the procedure" [4]. I think this means it is very likely the European Parliament shall be informed promptly after the signing — which would count as "requesting consent" — by the European Commission,  almost certainly (?) before 1 January. [1] https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/press/press-releases/2020/12/29/eu-uk-trade-and-cooperation-agreement-council-adopts-decision-on-the-signing/
[2] https://trade.ec.europa.eu/doclib/docs/2012/june/tradoc_149616.pdf
[3] https://data.consilium.europa.eu/doc/document/CM-5525-2020-INIT/en/pdf
[4] https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/?uri=CELEX%3A12008E218

Following the clarification noted above on 28 December, I have amended my forecast radically. The clarification above indicates to me, i.e. my interpretation thereof, is that an EU provisional agreement does not resolve the question in the positive.

I have no idea whether the specifics of the question have or will be fulfilled and I do not have the time to navigate what seems from the comments to be both complex and controversial. So I am going to hedge.

Go with @Wildwood2000
I understand the need to be precise but I feel the issue which was important and hard to predict was weather any deal was to be signed, which will occur tomorrow. 
Spending hours into browsing the contorted EU website is a waste of time, and wont make me a better forecaster if I find the solution #23 there.

@Wildwood2000 @Mark_T I retain my position of 100% albeit the EU Parliament has stated it will only vote on the deal in February or possibly even in March. See https://www.bloomberg.com/news/videos/2020-12-28/eu-lawmaker-gozi-on-brexit-deal-european-parliament-ratification-video. This has been confirmed by David McAllister of the EU. See https://bloom.bg/3nWeLnr. THe EU Ambassadors have approved the deal ( https://bloom.bg/37TRD36 ) and hence, it appears that in one way or another, the EU Council has 'requested' the EU Parliament (stage 23 / 'saisine') to proceed with the approval. In other words, a 'provisional' agreement has been reached to approve the trade agreement. This, IMO, while this does not make the trade agreement legal and enforceable at this moment in time, it is up to the adjudicators at gjopen to determine if the question is resolved in the positive or negative.

Today’s the day where the chips fall one side or the other! Thanks @User01 for a very cogent argument (with CETA precedent) for this happening by the deadline, and to @Wildwood2000 and @samglover97  for their equally well formed posits on the other side. As I see it the counter weights that are trying to tip the argument away from the crowd’s position are: 1. the lack of imperative to rush this through given that WTO trade terms are avoided though application of the provisional agreement (stage 22 which in this case seems to be taking place in parallel / out of sequence to the rest of the process).  This is in with the 27 EU ambassadors agreement as of yesterday (https://www.politico.eu/article/eu-ambassadors-approve-brexit-trade-deal/). 2. The UK parliament voting on the 30th December 2020, which appears to be an important aspect of stage 21’s “ The two negotiating sides formally sign the agreement” (which in itself is a key precursor to stage 23’s consent request to the EU Parl which we’ve been told by GJ(O) yesterday is the only accepted criteria for question resolution). The fully committed hedgehog / chimp in me desperately wants @User01 to be right, but the “system 2” fox is steadily talking me around to making a hard correction downwards. With “hard Brexit” / WTO terms no longer driving the process, the fundamental question as I see it is “what’s the rush to request consent?”. In the HIGHLY unlikely event the vote in the UK parliament goes south on the 30th Dec 20 it would seem easier and less reputationaly damaging for the Commission and the Council of the EU to simply withdraw provisional arrangements than if they were to bust their own process in requesting consent today (without the UK parliament’s ratified signature) and then have to reverse course before the EU Parl (and the world) tomorrow in the event the UK Parliament vote pulls the carpet out from under them. As a final negotiating tactic, and given BJ’s / the ERG’s / the UK Parliaments inherent unreliability and untrustworthiness (see the UK’s Internal Markets Bill fiasco) the EU may feel it far better (and more true to their own process) to hold the sword of Damocles over the UK Parliament’s head until after the UK vote on the 30th Dec 20 by keeping things “provisional” and only sending the consent request when the UK as a whole is fully signed up to what the BJ government has proposed. To be updated after a read out on what today’s written consent covers and if, as @User01 and @LunaSol suggest, it follows CETA’s precedent.  Being thorough I guess there is also the outside chance that consent could be requested on the 31st December 20 but why would EU Council members spend their New Year’s Eve (https://www.afar.com/magazine/the-strangest-new-years-eve-traditions-around-europe) on this when it could happily wait until the new year (when the EU’s MEPs have already said they’re happy to review and vote in slower time)? Again, what’s the rush? Thanks to Ryan at the GJ(O) for the clarification statement yesterday afternoon.  This has definitely been a good lesson in RTFQ - “read the FULL question”!

I proudly wrote a very long, well cited rationale to explain why I'm all in, then deleted it by accident. Phucque... (Karma Gods?)  A very brief synopsis follows: The Canada CETA example the questioners pointed us to, AND the press today re UK-EU deal all speak of a "Written Procedure" in which *all three asks* occur in one agreement/document. https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/press/press-releases/2016/10/28/eu-canada-trade-agreement/#  Excerpt: On 28 October 2016, the Council adopted by *Written Procedure* a package of decisions on the comprehensive economic and trade agreement with Canada (CETA), including:     a decision on signature of the agreement (Step 21)
    a decision on the provisional application of the agreement (Step 22)
    a decision to request the consent of the European Parliament for the conclusion of the agreement (Step 23!)  At the end of the day, I'm going with @User01and his arguments  and not with @Wildwood2000 and his. Two very capable debaters, eh?! @fisherdbus @DippySkippy @LunaSol @DelapsusAngelus @pstamp maybe revisit one more time?

Yep zero: The Council, acting by the unanimity of all 27 Member States, will then need to adopt a decision authorising the signature of the Agreement and its provisional application as of 1 January 2021. Once this process is concluded, the Trade and Cooperation Agreement between the EU and the UK can be formally signed. The European Parliament will then be asked to give its consent to the Agreement.

Albeit I am questioning how this will be resolved, i.e. simply when EU Council requests EU parliament to proceed with its procedures to approve the agreement or whether it would be after the EU Parliament would conclude its procedures and vote to agree, based on this https://reut.rs/34PyEFf which implies that Council will approve the agreement and thereby request Parliament's agreement, I am sticking with 100%. Looking at the quoted example in the question information with the CETA [https://bit.ly/3ps6S9w],  I am inclined to interpret the question as the cimple act of requesting Parliament rather than Parliament completing it stages 23-31

Moving up 10% based on today's reporting of unanimous backing the deal has received from the 27 EU member states (for PROVISIONAL implementation of trade arrangements between the EU and the UK). https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2020/dec/28/eu-member-states-unanimously-back-brexit-trade-security-deal Leaving 5% on the table in case: 1.  the well debated technicalities on EU process and specific terminology within this question (see this excellent thread discussion with @Wildwood2000, @User01, @samglover97 and @DelapsusAngelus: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1207887) catch us all out in a cruel (and slightly pedantic) trick! 2.  provisional acceptance of a deal (avoiding WTO trading terms as described in the original question) is not considered conclusive to this forecasting question by the OP (clarification has been sought, no response received as yet). Thanks to @User01 for this cogent, timely and very pertinent update: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1208640. Remember folks, the Brier Score is not the point: the analytical journey is.  If we get stumped at the 59th minute by a technicality in the question we'd all still do what we'd have done if we got it spot on:  we identify what we got right (and do more of it), we review what we got wrong (and do things differently) and we move on to the next question. While there is a small degree of room for error I am Maintaining at 100% - posting this comment for others. The Council of the EU has agreed to accept the deal.[1]  This means that all stages up until stage 20 in the documented noted in the question [2] have now been completed. For this to be official the Council must agree by written procedure - expected tomorrow.  Yet, as has seemed to have caused some confusion, the question rests on whether consent has been sought to conclude from the Parliament. Below is research I have posted in other comments (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1208354):  The EU-UK process is very similar to the agreement with Canada. One of the texts noted in the question clarifies what happened in the past with CETA [3] and this gives us an insight into the process in general.   The CETA written procedure contained a decision to request the consent of the European Parliament for the conclusion of the agreement.[4] Consent was then granted by the Parliament a few months after it was requested.[5] The only real difference to the process I can see is the competencies of the EU in each deal. CETA was a mixed deal whereas the Commission has chosen Article 217 TFEU as the legal basis for the conclusion of the EU-UK Agreement and deems it EU competence only.  The EU Commission has made clear its thoughts on the way forward in this press release [6] which states:  "In light of these exceptional circumstances, the Commission proposes to apply the Agreement on a provisional basis, for a limited period of time until 28 February 2021. The Commission will swiftly propose Council decisions on the signature and provisional application, and on the conclusion of the Agreement. The Council, acting by the unanimity of all 27 Member States, will then need to adopt a decision authorising the signature of the Agreement and its provisional application as of 1 January 2021. Once this process is concluded, the Trade and Cooperation Agreement between the EU and the UK can be formally signed. The European Parliament will then be asked to give its consent to the Agreement. As a last step on the EU side, the Council must adopt the decision on the conclusion of the Agreement." To me it is clear that the outlined in the press release brings the agreement to stage 23/24 as detailed by the EU's process document noted in the question.[2] Consent of the EU Parliament will be requested after the agreement is signed subject to provisional application on the EU's side, before the end of December. The consent procedure is an official a specialised legislative procedure used by the EU for international agreements.[7] [1] https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2020/dec/28/eu-member-states-unanimously-back-brexit-trade-security-deal

Increased original forecast by 4% on the basis that this seemed to be the more major of the two remaining sticking points and taking this as a sign that the largely political chest beating of UK Gov is now giving way to more rational (and fundamental) economic realities. Interesting the government supportive elements of the UK press (Sky News: https://news.sky.com/video/how-would-a-no-deal-brexit-affect-the-price-of-food-12161677) are today suddenly explaining the painful realities of a no deal in public / consumer focused terms.  Perhaps laying a soft landing ground for "Bendy Boris'" (now characteristic) U-Turn on previously held red lines? I'll leave 8% on the table to account for any incompetence / stupidity / hedgehog myopia in the political space that would allow a deal to fail through overplayed intransience (unlikely but not incredible).  The economically irrelevant (0.1%) sticking point of fishing rights is a political football playing almost exclusively to the Farage fan base at this stage (https://www.dw.com/en/uk-fishing-industry-or-brexits-red-herrings/a-51418061).  I don't see this being the hill that Boris will be willing to see his Churchillian persona die on, but if he overplays his now tedious bluff the EU might just decide to make him die on it anyway. COVID impacts have played a major part in forcing the UK's hand (whether they like it or not) which has also increased likelihood of a deal being struck despite rhetoric and media soundbites.  COVID impact and incoming austerity round 2 has pushed the likelihood of a deal up significantly given the obvious economic and fiscal requirement to mitigate a double hit at the same time. I've maintained that BJ and his finite Brexit gameplay cannot afford to have hard Brexit reality visited upon the UK, particularly the parts that will be hardest hit (which ironically mirror much of the UK voting base that most fervently demanded it).  Such a hard truth revelation would sink him and any legacy he might leave behind and is, as an objective factor, a more reliable forecasting indicator than the words of a proven liar and the press releases of a government trying desperately to maintain a poker face with a rapidly weakening hand of cards. Had the UK invested real time and effort into more serious, effective and sincere preparations for no deal Brexit a long time ago (infrastructure projects take time!) then there would be more indicators that the UK was genuinely entertaining no deal as an intentional / desirable outcome and were making best efforts to mitigating the impact of the hard landing.  Again, these are more objective and (to my mind) reliable indicators of intent and will than soundbites and press releases. Human beings communicate in two ways: words and actions.  Words come cheap and are forgotten quickly: actions speak louder. Important to note that the UKs concession on the evolution clause does nothing to reduce the likelihood of the UK diverging from  EU standards in the post deal era: it simply increases the likelihood of a deal before 1st Jan 2021 that the UK may then renege on at some stage(s) in the future. Such a breach  would result in tariffs on divergent UK goods to the EU; driving UK export prices up to the profit of the EU and at the cost of price rises for UK consumers, lost business for UK industries and the further demonization of the EU by an increasingly nationalist UK government and a predictably xenophobic right wing UK press.

I believe the key to making this forecast is remembering that people communicate with each other in two ways: by word and by deed.  When it comes to populists in general, and to this populist driven political theatre in particular, I believe it more important to weigh the communication of actions far higher than the communication of vitriolic / jingoistic / emotive / patriotic words. I've held off on making any forecast on Brexit until the last few days for precisely this reason.  In the last 48 hours we have seen some significant communicative actions which give us reason to see the UK Governments true position despite (and often in opposition to) the communications strategy they are electing to employ. I have weighted the UK Governments published agreement to not renege on the withdrawal agreement through the Internal Markets Bill or the Finance Bill above all other published statements and press briefings.  This indicates a willingness to compromise and, more importantly, see the UK government (which at this point is inextricable from BJ himself) finally choosing a side.  Which appears not to be the ERG. Whilst the ERG is certainly a vocal force and one the Conservative party find themselves gripped by, their reach into the general public consciousness appears to be waning significantly as Brexit reality approaches and the general unpreparedness of the UK to enter a no deal scenario with stability becomes more and more apparent. BJ, as a modern populist, will be very conscious of the popular mood and, with this decision to remove the law breaking aspects of the IM bill and the FA, appears to be demonstrating a willingness to risk the ERG's wrath as a preferable alternative to not wrecking the UK economy and seeing his flag go down with the sinking Brexit ship.  With this prediction I also see the likelihood of Boris being gone by this time next year significantly increase under cause - effect logic. In counter-argument, I still believe there is an outside possibility (currently 18%) of an "accidental no deal" Brexit scenario manifesting where Boris' brinksmanship pushes the negotiations too far and the EU decide that the financial pain they will feel from a no deal is preferable to continuing with fruitless negotiations and political gamesmanship. It still appears possible that they may decide to let the UK taste the reality of no deal in order to bring a more humble and pliable UK to the negotiating table in Q1/2 2021.  In the current economic climate created by COVID and the level of preparedness the EU enjoys to buffer no deal impacts their side however, a deliberately self harming decision from the EU along these lines, or an irreconcilable fait accompli created by the EU's red lines and a suicidally intractable BJ, seems to me to sit within the >20% range. To be adjusted on an hour by hour basis given current events!

I think the two sides are way too far apart too strike any significant deal right now. The conservatives under Boris have two ideological goals with Brexit. One is Global Britain; the idea of more trade deals, less regulation, lower taxes, and more high-skilled immigration. The second is the Dominic Cummings-David Deutsch argument (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xdtssXITXuE) that outside of the EU Britain would have the flexibilty to adapt to changing circumstances, quicker error-correction, and more visible democratic institutions. The Theresa May style Brexit which focused entirely on the immigration argument, and doing as least economic damage as possible is no longer the strategy. 
Under the red-lines now being set by Macron of further hardlines on state-aid, competition, and taxes being tied to the EU, means that Boris cannot hit his aims. There isn't even room to compromise on this issue. Throw in the nationalistic and politically charged fisheries argument, means that Boris would be removed as leader if he accepted the deal. 
A mini deal that lessens the effects of No-deal Brexit is still possible however.

It looks like the ground is set for some type of a compromise where the UK basically gets tariff-free access on trade goods, and in return for that it signs up to EU state aid rules and a level playing field, probably semi-fudged with some kind of 'independent' arbitrator. (I leave fish out of this because without a deal the UK anyway gets its fish). From the outside, it looks as if the UK government is eager (even desperate) to get anything that is acceptable enough that they can bring back and say it satisfies the requirements of Brexit, and the above example is basically the only example I imagine is likely to be agreed that fits those requirements (provided that it is agreed that some day in the future the UK will get its fish back, subject to further negotiations). However, trying to imagine what is going on on the inside I would observe that: To the extent that Boris Johnson has a political philosophy, it is clear that one of the things it involves is massive amounts of public spending and investment.  I think it is actually a credible policy to essentially borrow massive amounts of money now (interest rates happen to be low) and invest that money in a certain number of key industries (microprocessors, deep learning, etc) in order to give UK companies a head-start in building the economy of the 2030s. Therefore I would suggest that it does not make sense for him to sign up to EU state aid rules and a level playing field.  So on the basis that I don't think there is a deal on offer that the UK actually should accept (but I accept that it looks like there is a strong likelihood they will anyway), I lower my forecast from 50% to 45%.

Reports state that there are two sticking points preventing a trade deal between the UK and EU.
The first are for competition rules (the level playing field) to avoid undercutting of costs and ‘dumping’ UK products in a regulated EU Market and subsidies for Industry. This must be a moot point as both the French and German governments have a history of doing just that; more so than UK governments.
The second that is more politically sensitive and much less in a commercial sense which is the fishing industry. Fishing contributes a minor portion to the EU Countries or UK GDP, but promises have been made by politicians on both sides.
Traditionally negotiations go to the wire in EU negotiations and a last-minute deal could be achieved to avoid disruptions in trade.

Time Is Running Out to Enact Any Trade Deal With UK: EU Lawmakers.
*
Baczynska and Chalmers (2020). Nov. 6, stated that:
*
BRUSSELS (Reuters) - European lawmakers said on Friday time was running out to put in place any new trade agreement between London and the European Union before the end of an 11-month transition period following Britain’s departure from the bloc (Para. 1).
“Given how far away we are from a deal, that seems increasingly unlikely,” said one European Parliament official. “Time for ratification is running out” (Para. 8). A senior EU lawmaker who took part in Friday’s meeting said that once an agreement was reached, it would have to be scrutinised by experts in many fields and translated into various languages. “It’s getting tight,” the lawmaker said, adding that if the parliament is to ratify any agreement at a plenary sitting on Dec. 16, it will have to have the full text by Nov. 16 (Para 8-10).
*

2 things need to happen:
 - UK-EU negotiations have to conclude in time with a positive outcome   "p(A)"
 - EU Council (27 members) must approve of the deal and request Parl consent in time   "p(B|A)" For me p(A) depends entirely on whether the UK side caves on fish, state aid and its implementation of the Northern Ireland Protocol.  For now I'll assume this is 60%. I think p(B|A) is very high.  I'm going to say 98%.  France and Ireland will only say no at Council if the Commission's deal falls short of their expectations on fish/state aid and NI respectively. I don't believe the Commission will agree a deal that they think France or Ireland won't like. There is tiny risk of something mental happening like Spain bringing up Gibraltar at the last minute and subsequently being allowed to torpedo the trade deal. This is why 98% rather than 100%. So my forecast is 60% * 98% = 59% The main moving part of this will be my perception of what the UK side is likely to do.

EU and UK both amenable to extensions - think it is quite likely that a deal is reached, but not definitely before 01/01/21. That being said - the chance is not incredibly high because the extension (as far as I understand in the briefing file) must be for at least one year, which there will not be much appetite for in the UK. Really difficult to judge because on the one hand UK has shown itself to be willing to extend and COVID constitutes an exceptional circumstance that could politically justify extension but on the other hand Johnson made his 2019 campaign about getting Brexit done and could (in my view, only in the short term) lose support among Leave voters if he extends for one year.

Central in this question is the date of 1/1/21.
I am not an expert in any of the relevant fields, but I can imagine 4 things happening by that date:
1. A comprehensive trade agreement is reached
2. One or more smaller trade agreements are reached and negotiations continue in some other form
3. The transition period is extended
4. Negotiations break down and the outcome is a no deal Brexit.

1&2 lead to yes and 3&4 lead to no. 1. Looking at how the negotiations are proceeding, the politics involved and the process so far, I estimate the chance at about 21%
2. Small(er) trade agreements could be a way forward, but smaller agreements also change the playing field and reduce pressure. Potentially making it even harder to reach a deal on more difficult issues.  I estimate that negotiators will not like to lose their room to manoeuvre. Chance of this scenario happening: 11%
3. Boris and others have often said that they would not extend the transition period. Many would like this to be finally over. Nevertheless, an extension in some form cannot really be ruled out imho. There is the covid-crisis, the pressure is very high, it happened before with the withdrawal agreement and other deadlines. Chance about 51%.
4. The way I look at it, a hard Brexit will hit all parties hard on many levels. I don't think either party wants this, as many would suffer. However, as the EU is the larger party, it will be relatively easier for the EU to deal with the effect of a hard Brexit.  I also think the negotiation position of the EU, after a hard Brexit will be much better and it will relatively become easier for the EU to make advantageous deals after a hard Brexit. In this sense, it is up to the UK to find the path to a deal. Nevertheless, many in the UK believe a hard Brexit is advantageous to the UK and at some point, it might be difficult politically, to steer away from such an outcome. My estimate: 17%

The definition of a Trade agreement is required to give a definitive answer. My opinion is that there are two possibilities and they are:
a)	 (7% chance) - An all-embracing trade deal encompassing the full gamut of the relationships between the EU members and the UK  (preferred by the EU) and
b)	(75%+ chance) - A skeletal or umbrella agreement under which lie a series of specific arrangements that refer to a particular subject and can be added to or deleted at a later stage (the preference of the UK).
The UK government won the 2019 election with a determination to leave the EU, deal or no deal. The law was then passed to ensure there would be no extension to the transition period which ends 31st  December 2020.
An agreement in principle would have had to be completed by July 30, 2020 for presentation to the EU Parliament to meet the timetable. This date has passed.
During the negotiations,  6 red lines have become apparent that both sides refuse to cross, and they are:
1)	Fishing. The EU wish to keep the status quo in allowing their fishing industry to have unrestricted  and unfettered access to UK sovereign territory. The UK is insisting on regaining control over its seas and suggesting a yearly negotiated quota system.
2)	Level Playing Field. The EU is demanding that the UK is subjected to European standards after Brexit as in taxation, environment labour rights and state aid. The UK suggests this is not a consideration in any other trade agreement the EU has negotiated and is unacceptable and not conducive to an independent country and reserves the right to diverge.
3)	The European Court of Justice. The EU is insisting that the ECJ is the sole arbiter of contract disputations that may occur. Not acceptable responds the UK as an independent party should be used.
4)	Criminal Justice. The EU wants to retain the status quo by retaining the arrest warrant system. The UK disagrees.
5)	Cultural Objects. With Elgin Marbles in mind compliments of Greece, the EU insists that all cultural objects be returned to their place of origin. The UK disagrees.
6)	Financial Services. The EU insists that the City of London will lose its passport rights to operate in Europe. This is a major industry of the UK and as such is protected by the UK.
The EU sees the UK as trying to ‘cherry pick’ the benefits of belonging to the EU while abrogating actual membership.
The UK, after the Brexit referendum, European Election and General election sees it as listening to the will of the people and regaining its sovereignty as an independent country.
Therefore, I propose a minimum chance of a comprehensive trade agreement being offered to the European Parliament by the Council of the European Union.
It is contentious whether a skeletal umbrella agreement is necessary before 1st January 2021 that would be followed up by later deals, which I suggest is the probable outcome. 
Constant observation and potential updating is required for this forecast as pragmatism and politics are in a state of flux.

Britain will unfortunately experience disillusionment twice.  First it was the realization (or perhaps perception) that membership within the EU leads to more problems and less economic gains, hampering British society.  Second was the belief that exiting the EU would create greater economic gains, freedom, and autonomy from the laws and governance of EU meddle. Britain will win on its borders and prevent the currently unabated immigration flows.  But economically it’s tenuous.  The EU recognizes UK as an economic powerhouse and believes that unrestricted governance will lead to state aid influence, potentially preying on the 450 million weakened euro populace. The economic vacuum is too great for the EU to let go willfully.  So the EU seeks a “level playing field”, which means preventing Britain from succeeding through independence.   Any bilateral agreement to access the EU population will constrain the UK, exactly that which it seeks to
escape, and limit the foreseeable dreams of independent growth.  Instead they will test the alternative, WTO tariffs, utilize state aid as necessary (with the EU budget savings) to offset the WTO effect, and allow time to vanquish the acrimonious Brexit hangover.  At that point conducive talks will take place. The scope of the endeavor is currently in discovery and it is that discovery process which will uncover facets of the future relationship.  But it is clear the EU will initially suffer without a financial beacon in Britain.

Given that talks are deadlocked and we are in the middle of the coronavirus pandemic which has hit our economy (and everybody else's) hard and created a lot of extra spending and resource diverting that hadn't been forecast when the withdrawal agreement was announced, a trade deal is likely - tariffs off the back of Covid-19 are in nobody's interest, especially in the face of mass unemployment, so if there's a second wave it won't happen before 1st Jan.  While the pressure is more likely to come from the UK side - wanting to look as though we have 'concluded' Brexit, in fact starting the reality of what that means...very little progress continues to be made.  Everybody wants clarity, but who will blink first? The EU has stronger cards, always did. 2 year self-imposed deadline was ambitious, bordering on unrealistic. EU-Canada took about 5-6 years. EU-Japan was 2-3 but without surprise pandemic distractions. (https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2019/02/16/why-the-eu-japan-trade-deal-matters-for-brexit/). Too much at stake, too much to lose if not scrutinised properly and we are all more vulnerable because of Covid. Fish is an interesting conversation to follow.  Deep down the EU probably still hopes that sentiment changes enough over time that the effects of us leaving become less extreme, so I doubt they would insist on concluding talks by 1st Jan, more likely to come from us. But with regards to trading with other nations, a significant part of what made the UK attractive to investors was the UK's access to Europe (ask Japan). With that now mainly neutered, the offers are likely to be less favourable than current terms as we have less leverage. With less attractive trade deals on the table due to more protectionist current policies around the world, getting a good FTA with the EU while still leaving becomes the best goal in the circumstances. It just depends on how insoluble those two prove to be.  To that end, having another 'interim' measure is another possibility - to appear that we are moving forward - not an 'extension to the transition period'. More like the first phase of a 'pre-trade deal' period, but with very little actually sorted out. Or a 'partial deal'. Same same.  Optics are all important - how to manoeuvre without either side looking like they have 'lost'. That is an art in itself. Looking like we 'mean business' by saying there will be no transition extension is about trying to secure better terms, but I'm not sure how convincing that as we fast approach the deadline without having made much progress that competes favourably with our current trade arrangements. We should know more next week after the meeting of BJ and EvdL.

Petrequin, S. (2020). EU, UK leaders to meet this month as post-Brexit talks stall. Associated Press. June 2, 2020. Retrieved from
https://www.stltoday.com/business/eu-uk-leaders-to-meet-this-month-as-post-brexit-talks-stall/article_446c416a-d24d-5294-bc05-f1fe0dc99c49.html BRUSSELS (AP) — The European Union's top executive and British Prime Minister Boris Johnson will meet this month for talks that could give new momentum to the stalled post-Brexit negotiations. As a fourth round of talks between teams of negotiators resumed Tuesday with little hope for a breakthrough on a future trade deal, the bloc's executive arm said a meeting is planned between EU Commission President Ursula von der Leyen and Johnson by the end of June. Daniel Ferrie, the commission spokesperson for EU-U.K. negotiations, said the date and format of the encounter have yet to be determined. The U.K. left the political institutions of the EU on Jan. 31, but remains inside the EU’s tariff-free single market and customs union until the end of the year. That so-called transition period can be extended by two years although a deal to do so has to be made by July 1, according to the legal documents accompanying Brexit. Johnson has repeatedly said he will not extend the transition period beyond Dec. 31.

The idea of a bare bones deal still seems achievable if UK moves on level playing field conditions (LPF) & seemingly total denial of EU fleet access to UK waters. If they want to conclude a trade deal LPF conditions will play a part in that but how much clearly up for negotiation. Really think a lot of people are undercooking the likelihood of a deal. Essentially Johnson and Varadkar sat down in a room and sorted it. Phase 2 will be more complex due to the interests of various parties in fish but a deal is achievable if UK accept that access to EU markets means they cannot expect to deny EU fleet any access at all to UK waters. June talks will be V significant as is last opportunity for an extension to be granted. When June concludes the outcome will become binary , deal or “no-deal”. Canada, Ukraine, and Switzerland have agreements with the EU which partially resemble what a UK-EU trade deal may look like. It took an average of 6.3 years to negotiate these deals. The current health crisis means that negotiations will happen via video conference for at least the next few months. The timetable has not changed but this will probably impact the efficiency of the talks. The big disagreement at this stage is the enforcement of a/the ‘level playing field’. The EU wants to maintain the integrity of the single market and prevent unfair practice. They want disputes to be handled by the European Court of Justice (ECJ). This is a red line from the UK’s perspective, remaining subject to the ECJ means they are rule takers and undermines Brexit. There are solutions to this problem such as dynamic alignment, but this is not very popular with the UK as it would still involve the ECJ. This may be the brick wall leading to a no/WTO trade deal. The British Government has made its position very clear about not having an extension [1]. Currently British law does not allow the request for an extension. Both of these points need to be taken with a grain of salt (the withdrawal agreement negotiations). The UK has warned the EU that they could ditch talks in June if a clear framework for a free trade deal is not in place [2]. A tough approach may increase the chances of an agreement. But, the chances of a deal will diminish if negotiations are ditched. A full agreement before Jan 1st 2021 seems unlikely. A partial agreement is much more probable. If a full agreement is not in place coming up to the deadline, there will be an incentive from both sides to push through a smaller deal consisting of everything they DO agree on. Especially because of the health crisis and economic slowdown. However, the ‘nothing is agreed until everything is agreed’ mantra will probably surface once again due to ‘linkage’ [3], reducing the chances of a partial agreement. Overall, negotiating a deal like this in 10 months is extremely difficult, unprecedented. The health crisis makes it even more so. However, A partial agreement is certainly possible and could come at the very last minute. Criticism is very welcome! [1] https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-52313042
[2] https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-51650961
[3] https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-51657084

Nationalism and populism have proven to be a recurring issue in Europe, being the drive for events such as Brexit and the increasing distrust towards organizations such as the European Union (EU) (https://www.statista.com/topics/3291/right-wing-populism-in-the-european-union/). Naturally, as this is a matter that will make or break the EU's entire survival, the EU would do anything it can to discourage more states from leaving the EU. Thus, while forcing a hard Brexit would hurt it economically, we would assume that the EU would need to hardline, as other nations who are skeptical of the EU would see how costly it would be to leave their experiment, and would be compelled to stay with the Union. Plus, Brexit has been going on for years now, and it would seem that given the reduced coverage of Brexit, people are less interested in saving the UK, and are more willing to say "good riddance." Thus, before recent events, I would say that there was a good chance, probably a 66% chance, that the trade agreement would be concluded. However, this ignores the elephant in the room, the one thing we can't seem to ignore these days, the pandemic that has currently plagued the world. Unfortunately, globalism and multilateralism, to values I personally believe in and I will acknowledge may bias my ability to accurately predict events, are under fire more than ever before (https://www.realclearpolitics.com/2020/03/15/globalization_may_be_the_greatest_victim_of_covid-19_504495.html). This is a "problem without passport" and thus requires international consensus, but there are many who wish to blame increased globalization for this problem occuring in the first place. Naturally, one would assume that the forecoming rise of populism would mean that the EU and even EU skeptics would use this opportunity to double down on finalizing the agreement. They would want to end the relationship between the EU and the UK sooner rather than later. However, I now feel that the economic consequences of leaving the EU are now too severe for the entire world. The stock market is seeing multiple record breaking drops due to a loss of faith in the American government's ability to handle the crisis (https://www.vox.com/2020/3/16/21182341/dow-jones-biggest-point-drop-coronavirus-3000). Meanwhile, unemployment rates in the world's largest economy are reaching levels not seen since WWII (https://www.npr.org/sections/coronavirus-live-updates/2020/03/31/824520791/economy-on-lockdown-jobless-rate-could-be-highest-since-wwii). This is just mentioning one country who happens to be a significant trading partner to both the UK and the EU. The world is headed to economic turmoil, and at this point Brexit may only worsen things. So instead of significantly guaranteeing that Brexit will finally come to an end by next year, I am giving this a 50% shot.  Now to apply Bayesian Theorem, P(A|B)= P(B|A)* P(A) /P(B)
A, B	=events. Where A is hard Brexit and B is the economic ramifications of Coronavirus 
P(A|B)=probability of A given B is true, or what we are looking for
P(B|A)=probability of B given A is true, or the probability that  we will have a hard Brexit due to the economic ramifications of coronavirus (50%)
P(A), P(B)=the independent probabilities of A and B (66% for a Hard Brexit and a 75% chance that there are economic ramifications) meaning that P(A|B)= (.5)(.66)/(.75)=.44 or a 44% chance that the Council of the European Union will request the consent of the European Parliament to conclude a European Union-United Kingdom trade agreement

- It usually takes several months after an FTA negotiating is finalised for the Council of the EU to request the consent of the EP. Given that negotiations are far from being completed, the base probability is very low, around 5%.
- While other FTA negotiations do not have a deadline, this one does. The transition period is supposed to end on the 31 December 2020, and there is a strong incentive for both parties to complete that negotiations, as otherwise, the WTO regime would apply and neither side wants to see this happen.  In addition, both parties know each other well so their rules are already aligned as the UK was part of the EU for decades. This raises the probability significantly to reach a total of around 65-75%
- There is an interest from the UK to depart from the EU's approach to validate its rationale for withdrawing. This will likely be accompanied by actions that will be concerning for EU member state's interests, thus slowing down negotiations. Probability reduced by 10%
- The UK wants access to the EU single market and all its benefits, but not the related rules. It is unlikely the EU will offer to a non member all the benefits of a member as this would be a bad precedent putting the whole EU project at risk. While some of this was already addressed during the previous negotiations, the details in all relevant sectors will be important. Again, this will make negotiations difficult. Probability reduced by another 10%
- The negotiations are extremely complex given the integration in so many policy  areas, and both parties have some incompatible red lines. Probability reduced by another 10%
- While there is a deadline for completion of the transition period, it is likely that an extension of the transition will be made. Even if short, this will delay by a few extra weeks the request for consent. Probability further reduced

Requesting the consent of EU Parliament before Jan 1, 2021 is dependent on 3 factors. 
1. Deal Negotiation speed - how many deals of this size and complexity get completed in less than an year 
2. Inclination of EU and UK to seal the agreement - Depends on how much UK needs EU and vice versa
3. Alternatives - Like major trade deals that UK can strike within this period that give it leverage in negotiations and thus make a quick agreement difficult. Also public backlash or industry pressure that forces UK to extend transition period beyond Dec 2020 would mean that trade negotiations get extended. Maximum weightage is given to Deal negotiation speed. A brief search on negotiation to approval process of trade deals + EU's own manual gives the average time of 6-7 years. Given the high focus on this deal, we can reduce this period to 5 years. This gives us 20% chance of a deal happening within the year. A coefficient of 0.5 pegs the value at 10%. Inclination is divided equally between UK and EU. With equal coefficient of 0.2 each, UK's need for EU is taken to be much higher (75% chance of deal happening). EU's need for UK is significant but France can hold out on certain key issues, thus bringing the chance down to an even keel (50%). Multiplying by coefficients gives us 15% and 10%. Alternatives would reduce the chance of a quick deal. equal coefficients are given to significant market FTA (e.g. US UK trade deal) and pressure for extending transition period beyond Dec 2020. Chances of a quickfire deal between US and UK are significant due to US election in November and need for quick wins on both sides (70% probablity). Extending transition has a very low probability due to law passed by UK and frequent statements by UK PM ruling it out. However industry pressure and public backlash can happen as July comes. (20% probability. With coefficients, the chances of a yes thus reduce by 4.5 %.  My estimate would put the chances currently as 30.5%

Updating Forecast: After reading more about how the Canada negotiations took 7 years and how there are already difficulties in finding consensus on important issues (like fishing, EU social and environmental standards), I am reducing my probability from 42% to 34%. I think the EU is going to hold firm and will not be "bullied" by the UK or their hard stances.

Both the UK and the European Union have an interest in avoiding a "no-deal" scenario, and it's possible that there will be sector-by-sector deals being made. On the other hand, the evidence suggests that the UK (and Ireland) will be harmed far more than most of the EU countries, which reduces the probability that the EU will be willing to do a deal. Meanwhile, many Brexiters are convinced that the UK will "manage" in a no-deal scenario, which reduces the probability that the UK will be willing to a deal. Impediments to a deal are significant, including arguments over regulatory alignment, fisheries and even Gibraltar.  The Withdrawal Deal was only agreed because Johnson pivoted to supporting a "NI-only backstop"; avoiding a hard border on the island of Ireland was one of the main reasons that both sides were desperate to at least agree a withdrawal deal. Now that that's been taken care of, there's less pressure to agree on a trade deal. Trade deals including CETA tend to take years to negotiate. All of that said, one shouldn't underestimate Mr Johnson's desire to get some sort of deal "for the cameras".

I think the timetable is too ambitious, considering the length of time it took to conclude BREXIT, and despite Boris Johnson's newfound political capital and both sides having a vested interest in a quick agreement. I think there is a higher probability the U.K. will seek more of a WTO trade option than any of the other proposed options (Norway option, Turkey option, Swiss option, Ukraine option, etc.) considering its tendency to completely withdrawal from the EU - signaling the likelihood of a trade option that is most favorable to the U.K. with the least strings attached to the E.U. - the option that presents it the most autonomy with the least ties and least E.U. influence, also increasing the likelihood of drawn-out negotiations as the E.U. seeks an option that implements more measures favorable to the E.U. I also think there is a lot of fear and hesitancy within the E.U. to a quick agreement with regard to potential economic impacts to a poorly conceived deal and quick end to the transition period (hard BREXIT) - increasing the probability of delays in the process as impacts are studied and new proposals/conditions negotiated. Because of this, I think it will be very difficult for the U.K.-E.U. to reach a "level playing field agreement" in the next 10-11 months, and a less than 40% chance the Council will request Parliamentary consent in concluding a trade deal.

Following the recent exit of the United Kingdom from the European Union, the next steps include securing a trade agreement to prevent a potential economic upset for the United Kingdom. The "Brexit" transition period is scheduled to end on 31 December 2020, though my prediction suggests only a 4% chance a trade agreement will be requested by that time.  The process, from start to enactment, for trade deal traditionally takes several years and involves 30 stages. Prior to being presented to the EU Council of EU Parliament, the EU Commission must first prepare and negotiate the proposal. The process includes lengthy steps, such as public consultation, draft proposals, and consultation with the Trade Policy Committee. Though several agreements have been made by the UK with other non-EU nations, these deals were determined as the EU allowed the UK to transfer existing agreements. Of the agreements completed since 2018, the amount only covers 8% of total UK trade. Additionally, relations between UK and EU leadership does not appear on good terms, with both sides expressing tough words to the media. Despite the obstacles, the UK has several incentives to ensure the process is initiated in a timely manner. A new trade agreement will help stop new tariffs coming into force after 31 December 2020. Seven of the top ten trading partners of the UK are in EU members. The failure to produce an agreement would leave the UK under WTO rules, applying tariffs on most goods, causing prices in the EU to skyrocket, and making products more difficult to sell. Based on the amount of time needed and conflict between leadership, only a 4% chance exists of a concluded agreement by 1 January 2021.
Yes. Not the agreement in its entirety, but a base-level agreement will have been made.

Even as 49% of the UK's trade is with the EU, it still runs a deficit, primarily as a result of goods with Germany and the Netherlands.  The economic impact to the EU members with which the UK has a goods deficit could be the shock that triggers economic uncertainty for long period.  While I suspect that the majority of UK exports to the EU could be shifted to EU members, the key industries such as parama and petroleum products would put the EU at a disadvantage.

Furthermore, in order to minimize the economic impact to the EU and sustain the ability of the EU to serve a function for its members, it too will give a little to have something by the end of the year.  Finally, I suspect that not everything will be settled, but sufficient agreement will be made to agree to postpone the rougher spots until after the New Year.

I forecast that there is a 23% chance that the Council of the European Union request the consent of the European Parliament to conclude a European Union-United Kingdom trade agreement.  The UK has historically traded very heavily with the EU (49% of total UK trade in 2018). Both the UK and the EU are invested in trade with one another. This item also remains a top priority on the list of negotiations between the two entities. However, PM Johnson's more hard-line, right-wing stance is likely to result in stagnation of negotiations as the UK seeks the most favorable terms possible. If the entire Brexit process has taught us anything, the EU is unlikely to accept being bullied by the UK. Therefore, negotiations are likely to stall frequently and delay progress in finalizing any deal before 1 January 2021.  It is worth noting that the UK can pursue bilateral trade deals with other countries (US, Canada, etc) during this process and is not entirely reliant on a trade deal being finalized on anything but favorable terms. Trade does not become impossible without a deal as the UK can still trade with the EU based on WTO rules (even if temporarily). However, I leave much room for an improvement in negotiations as there is potential for a "temporary trade deal" to be struck between the two parties that more or less serves as an "trade extension" in lieu of its political equivalent (something that PM Johnson has sworn not to undertake, let alone its Parliament). Therefore, there is a greater chance of a temporary deal being struck that, on its face, looks more favorable to the UK while maintaining many of the existing rules in place today.

The chances of negotiating a trade deal between the United Kingdom and the European Union seem less likely than not in this time frame. The alternatives are a well-developed trade deal (1-5% chance), a bare-bones free-trade deal with the details to be filled in later, or a hard exit by the end of the year in which it would default to the rules of the WTO (World Trade Organization).
